title.narrative: Training good agricultural practices and efficient irrigation for food security in the Ziway-Shalla Basin, Ethiopia

description.narrative: Within this project the following goals are pursued: - produce the basic knowledge for the better understanding of the functioning of the hydrology and hydrogeology of the area; - develop tailored training modules on agro-hydrology, improved irrigation and agricultural practices; - set up of a training program: including presentations and exercises in a workshop setting; - contribute to capacity building of local agricultural extension officers and make them water ambassadors; - support Meki Batu Union in their effort to make their members wisely use the available water resources in the area.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the Grant Obligations and Conditions, the obligatory dates for submission of the annual/additional reports are mentioned. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please **For TMT+:** Comment to what extent the outputs have been achieved. Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value: The training course contributed to the enhancement of theoretical and practical skills of individuals and organizations to support farmers in improving their agricultural and irrigation practices. Each theoretical morning session was turned into practice during the afternoon field sessions. The topics addressed closely matched the day-to-day extension works of the training participants. 41 scholarship holders have successfully completed the training course, out of which four were awarded to women, 12 to Meki Batu extension staff, four to supporting research staff, and a total of nine were awarded to farmers. More than 80% of the participants stated that they have acquired new knowledge and gained new skills, related to water management and agronomic practices. The training strengthened the capacity of staff from nine different private and public organizations.

comment.narrative: 10 Meki Batu extension officer (+14 supporting research staff) support implementation of new farming technologies and practice, develop new ideas and concepts from interdisciplinarity and try to influence policy

title.narrative: B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value: During the scoping mission the role of men and women in farming was discussed during field visits with participating organisations. Some of the organizations actively involve women as part of their implementing activities. Traditionally, the role of women is limited to farming tasks such as Narrative report - Tailor-Made Training - Orange Knowledge Programme Page 8 of 10 transplanting and post-processing of harvest in packhouses. Farmer cooperatives are mainly dominated by men, also in terms of land-holding. The training incorporated several female farmers to show that farming practices need not be only men-dominated practices. During the training week, special attention was given to women to share their knowledge and experience: both during theoretical sessions as well as during the practical field visits. This strengthened the position of women and raised awareness among the male farmers of the readily and well-developed knowledge available with female farmers. The number of female extension staff employed at the participating organizations and governmental bodies is limited or even negligible. Both within Meki Batu Union, as well as in the targeted woreda and kebele agricultural offices, no women are active in horticultural extension service provision. When asking, the participants indicated that this is likely to change in the near future, since an increasing number of female development agents (DAs) graduate nowadays from regional TVET colleges and are to enter extension office positions.

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value: In general, the training and its contents were really appreciated and considered ‘good to very good’, ‘very important’, and ‘this kind of training is to be continued in future’. Especially, the practical field training components were highly valued. Multiple participants stressed the importance of the training for raising awareness on the excessive water use within the Basin and the impact continuing these practices will have on the future existence of lake Ziway. This is not only important for current generation, but even more for future generations. Even though majority of the participants were born in the training area, they did not know and realize the insights shared on the Basin in Balance module. Participants stressed that the learnings will be passed on to farmers as well as colleagues who are also involved in the provision of extension services. Suggestions were given to provide the training materials in local language (Oromiffa) in order to enhance the understanding of the topics addressed.

title.narrative: III.O.4. Testimonials from employers on organisational changes (implemented procedure/techniques, work ethic etc.) due to trained staff (critical mass)
III.I.3. Narratives from alumni on policy and procedural changes, inclusive development, and innovations as a result of interventions

actual.value: The course touched upon a wide variety of elements prevalent during a growing season and of importance to extension staff in their service provision towards farmers (e.g. spraying techniques, agro-chemical dosing, crop water requirements and irrigation scheduling), which were both theoretically and practically examined by the training participants. During the training sessions and in visits to relevant local research institutes, the participants were introduced to new farming technologies (e.g. composting, mulching, drip irrigation and deficit irrigation) and improved extension materials (e.g. water sensitive spraying paper, simple soil test kit). As part of the training, a skill sheet on water management has been developed and distributed among the participants. Similarly, the local resource persons active in the SNV HortiLIFE project distributed skill sheets on good agricultural practices for the major crops in the region. The closing session was led by the general manager of Meki Batu Union, who distributed the training certificates.
